reg:regulation.reg:title: Cannabis Control and Licensing Interim Regulation

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;
original packaging, in respect of cannabis, means the packaging of the cannabis when it was purchased from the government;
retail store means all or part of a building or structure designated in a retail store licence to be the establishment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following classes of licences are established:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: retail store licence;
marketing licence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A retail store licence authorizes the licensee to sell cannabis referred to in section 15 (c) of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following rules and requirements apply to a retail store licence:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an adult who purchases cannabis from the retail store licensee must pay for and take personal possession of the cannabis at the retail store;
cannabis that is sold under the retail store licence must not be sold through an online system;
cannabis must not be consumed in the retail store;
cannabis that is sold under the retail store licence must be sold in its original packaging that has never been opened;
cannabis in its original packaging must not be opened by the retail store licensee unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the purpose of opening the packaging is to allow patrons to smell the cannabis, or another purpose approved by the general manager, and
cannabis from the opened packaging is not sold;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: only cannabis and cannabis accessories are permitted to be sold from a retail store;
the only business that takes place in the retail store is the sale of cannabis and cannabis accessories;
the retail store must not, in the general manager's opinion, appear to be associated, through signs, the use of trademarks or any other means, with another business other than another retail store;
the retail store must be located in a permanent building or structure and be enclosed by floor-to-ceiling walls that are not transparent;
the entrances and exits of the retail store must not be shared with any other store or business;
it must not be possible for patrons entering or exiting the retail store to pass through any other store or business other than

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the common area of a mall, or
an area approved by the general manager under paragraph (l) (ii);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the entrances or exits of the retail store must not require patrons to pass through an area that is enclosed to create exclusive access to the entrance or exit of the retail store and one or more other stores or businesses, other than an area that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the common area of a mall or a hallway, or
subject to subsection (2), an area approved by the general manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The general manager must not approve an area under subsection (1) (l) (ii) if the area provides access to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a business in which the majority of the goods or services offered for sale are primarily directed at minors, or

premises that are subject to a licence issued under the Liquor Control and Licensing Act that authorizes patrons to consume liquor, other than the consumption of samples, in the service area under the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, federal licensee means a person who holds a producer's licence issued under section 35 of the Access to Cannabis for Medical Purposes Regulations made under the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (Canada).
The general manager must not issue a retail store licence to or for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who has arranged, or agreed to arrange, with another person to sell the cannabis of a federal licensee to the exclusion of the cannabis of another federal licensee,
a federal licensee or the federal licensee's agent, or

a person who is so associated with, connected with or financially interested in a federal licensee or federal licensee's agent that the person is, in the general manager's opinion, likely to promote the sale of cannabis of the federal licensee.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restriction on number of retail store licences that may be held by applicants

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a corporation and any affiliate, within the meaning of section 2 of the Business Corporations Act, of the corporation,
an individual and any corporation that is controlled, within the meaning of section 2 of the Business Corporations Act, by the individual,
a person who is a partner in a general partnership and each of the partners,
a person who is a general partner in a limited partnership and each of the general partners, or
a person who is a partner in a limited liability partnership and each of the partners;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: significant shareholder, in respect of a corporation, means a person who holds or beneficially owns, other than by way of security only, 20% or more of any class of shares of the corporation that confer the right to vote for the election of directors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The general manager must not issue a retail store licence to an applicant if issuing the licence would result in the applicant or a group of related persons holding more than 8 retail store licences.

The general manager must not issue a retail store licence to an applicant if issuing the licence would result in more than 8 retail store licences being held by one or more corporations, referred to in paragraphs (a) to (c) as the licence-holding corporations, in any of the following situations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the same person is a significant shareholder in each of the licence-holding corporations;
one person is a significant shareholder in one or more corporations that are significant shareholders in each of the licence-holding corporations;

one person is a significant shareholder in one or more, but not all, of the licence-holding corporations, and each of the remaining licence-holding corporations has one or more significant shareholders that are corporations in which that person is a significant shareholder.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The general manager must not issue a retail store licence to an applicant if issuing the licence would, in the general manager's opinion, result in one person, through an association, connection or financial interest,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: likely having direct or indirect influence over licensees who hold more than 8 retail store licences,
likely being able to affect, directly or indirectly, the activities carried out under more than 8 retail store licences, or
having the influence referred to in paragraph (a) or the ability to affect activities referred to in paragraph (b) with respect to more than 8 retail store licences.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A marketing licence authorizes a licensee to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promote cannabis for the purpose of selling it,
solicit, receive and take orders for the sale or purchase of cannabis, and
act as an agent for the sale or purchase of cannabis.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prescribed class of licence — section 26 (4) of Act
bcl:section.bcl:text: The class of licence prescribed for the purposes of section 26 (4) of the Act is the marketing licence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consultation with local governments and Indigenous nations

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 33 (1) of the Act with respect to issuing licences, the prescribed class of licence is the retail store licence.
The prescribed criterion for the purposes of section 33 (3) of the Act is the location of a proposed retail store.
The prescribed circumstances for the purposes of section 33 (3) of the Act are that the issuance of the licence may affect nearby residents.
For the purposes of section 33 (4) of the Act, comments and recommendation must be given in accordance with the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the comments and recommendations must be in writing;
the comments must include the views of the local government or Indigenous nation on the general impact on the community;
if the local government or Indigenous nation has gathered the views of residents under section 33 (3) of the Act, the comments must include

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the views of the residents, and
a description of the method used to gather those views;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the recommendations must include whether the application should be approved or rejected;
the recommendations must include the reasons on which they are based.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Fit And Proper Determination by Security Manager

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, security manager means the security manager appointed under section 11.
The minister must appoint, under the Public Service Act, a security manager for the purposes of this Part.

In addition to the requirements set out in section 26 (2) of the Act, the general manager must not issue a licence if, in the security manager's opinion, the applicant for a licence is not fit and proper as determined in accordance with section 13.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: applicant means an applicant for a licence;
associate, in respect of an applicant, means a person that, in the security manager's opinion,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may have direct or indirect influence over the applicant, or
may be able to affect, directly or indirectly, the activities carried out under the licence applied for.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In determining whether an applicant is fit and proper, the security manager may take into account

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an associate of the applicant, and
a person who has a connection to an associate of the applicant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In determining whether an applicant is fit and proper, the security manager must conduct background investigations and the checks set out in subsection (4) that the security manager considers necessary in respect of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant,
an associate of the applicant that the security manager considers relevant, and
a person that the security manager considers relevant that has a connection to the associate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are the checks for the purposes of subsection (3):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a criminal record check or fingerprint-based criminal record verification by searching the Canadian Police Information Centre database;
a police information check;
a check of intelligence databases maintained by law enforcement agencies;
a check of records in the justice information system of the Ministry of Attorney General;
a check of records in the corrections information system of the Ministry of Public Safety and Solicitor General.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 10 of the Act applies to the security manager and references to the general manager in that section must be read as including the security manager.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ways to give or serve documents — general

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 122 (1) of the Act, a document that is required or allowed under the Act to be given or served on a person, other than the general manager, must be given or served in accordance with this section.
The ways to give or serve a document on an individual are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with the individual,
by leaving the document at the individual's residence with an adult who apparently resides with the individual,
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the address at which the individual resides or to a forwarding address provided by the individual,
by leaving the document in a mailbox or mail slot for the address at which the individual resides,
by attaching the document to a door or other conspicuous place at the address at which the individual resides,
by sending the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the individual, or
by transmitting the document to a fax number provided by the individual.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The ways to give or serve a document on a corporation are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with an officer or director of the corporation,
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the registered office of the corporation,
by sending a copy of the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the corporation, or
by transmitting a copy of the document to a fax number provided by the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The ways to give or serve a document on a partnership are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with a partner,
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the business office of the partnership,
by sending a copy of the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the partnership, or
by transmitting a copy of the document to a fax number provided by the partnership.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The ways to give or serve a document on an Indigenous nation are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with an elected official or administrative officer of the Indigenous nation,
by sending the document by ordinary mail or registered mail to the mailing address of the Indigenous nation or by courier to the administrative office of the Indigenous nation,
by sending a copy of the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the Indigenous nation, or
by transmitting a copy of the document to a fax number provided by the Indigenous nation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 122 (2) of the Act, a document given or served in accordance with section 15 of this regulation is conclusively deemed to be received,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is left with an individual, on the day it is left,
if the document is sent by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier, on the fifth day after it is mailed or received by the courier,
if the document is left in a mailbox or mail slot, on the third day after it is left,
if the document is attached to a door or other conspicuous place, on the third day after it is attached,
if the document is sent by electronic mail, on the third day after it is sent, and
if the document is transmitted to a fax number, on the third day after it is transmitted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ways to give or serve documents on general manager
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 122 (1) of the Act, a document that is required or allowed under the Act to be given or served on the general manager must be given or served in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with the general manager;
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the address of the general manager;
by sending the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address of the general manager;
by transmitting the document to a fax number of the general manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The fees payable under the Act and this regulation are set out in the Schedule.
All fees must be paid at the time that an application or request for anything referred to in the Schedule is submitted.
